body: We have `ORM\Query::cleanCopy()`. If we use the name `clean()` then `cleanCopy()` needs to call it or users will be confused.

> We have `ORM\Query::cleanCopy()`. If we use the name `clean()` then `cleanCopy()` needs to call it or users will be confused.

True! Any suggestions on a different name?

I thought about something like `clearData()`. So it's more in the spirit of cache but not exactly cache. But I feel users might confuse it with a `TRUNCATE`. I'm trying to avoid using the word "Result", so it doesn't conflict with `setResult()` and the property.

I am not sure the name is a problem. I think we could simply make the API more complete:

- `Query::clean()`
- `Query::cleanCopy()`
- `ORM\Query::cleanCopy()`

Both clean copies will clone and clean. `ORM\Query::cleanCopy()` would call `clean()` along with the cleanup it already does.
`Query::reset()` could work too. It wouldn't overlap with the existing `cleanCopy()` method.

`reset()` kind of feels like you're just resetting the iterator. `clean()` is a good name. 

I think I prefer consistent api over instead of trying to write one-off special cases. Users won't ask what the difference is "Why can't I just clone and reset ORM\Query?".

`Query::clean()` doesn't really tell me what parts of query it will clean. Without an additional qualifier one would think it clears all internal state.

I would prefer the name `Query::clearResult()`. It's tells you exactly what it does and the name is consistent with `Query::clearContain()` we already have.

> I'm trying to avoid using the word "Result", so it doesn't conflict with setResult() and the property.

How does it conflict?

> `Query::reset()` could work too. It wouldn't overlap with the existing `cleanCopy()` method.

I do like short names, though I feel @othercorey makes a good point regarding the iterator.

> `Query::clean()` doesn't really tell me what parts of query it will clean. Without an additional qualifier one would think it clears all internal state.
> 
> I would prefer the name `Query::clearResult()`. It's tells you exactly what it does and the name is consistent with `Query::clearContain()` we already have.

It probably should be `Query::clearResult()` in the sense that it is what users expect to find as well yeah. After sleeping on it, I do think `Query::clean()` might have the expectation of getting the same result as `Query::cleanCopy()` except for the clone/copy part which it won't.

> > I'm trying to avoid using the word "Result", so it doesn't conflict with setResult() and the property.
> 
> How does it conflict?

Just that `setResult()` is a setter for `QueryTrait::$_result` whereas this method would touch two properties instead. Tbh, I don't feel that strongly about it. I'm okay with naming it `Query::clearResult()`.
